item.title: Why VCs Will Never Give Us Money (And We're Okay With That)
item.author: John Luther
item.description:
Less than 1% of startups secure venture capital funding. At Limeleaf, we're part of that 99% – but by choice.

Since founding our company, a few people have asked how we plan to fund product development. Most assume we'll try to raise VC money. Today, we'll explain why we aren’t taking that approach and what we’re doing instead.

item.title: We Are Changing Our Domain
item.author: John Luther
item.description:
This morning, Blain educated me about the history of the .io top-level domain. I didn't know that history when I bought limeleaf.net last year before teaming up with Blain and Erik.

limeleaf.net wasn't available then, but to my surprise and delight, it was this morning, so I bought it.

All Limeleaf site traffic and email now redirect from limeleaf.io to limeleaf.net, and I have donated $50 to Chagossian Voices.

item.title: Step 0 of Starting a Tech Worker Co-Op: Define Your Goals
item.author: John Luther
item.description: Worker cooperatives ("co-ops") are a growing alternative to traditional hierarchical tech company structures, which often rely on venture capital funding. Unlike conventional startups that take VC money in exchange for an equity stake, co-ops prioritize worker ownership, democratic decision-making, and profit sharing and strive to embody the 7 Cooperative Principles established by the International Co-operative Alliance.

item.title: Safer Binary Decoding in Go
item.author: Blain Smith
item.description:
Go is a popular language choice for building web services. Typically, when building those web services, we end up encoding/decoding JSON as the data format. The encoding/json package provides a safe way to turn JSON payloads into Go structs, and vice versa.

However, if we need to handle raw []byte that follow a binary encoding format that is not self-describing, we need to do a bit more work and implement the encoding.BinaryMarshaler and encoding.BinaryUnmarshaler directly. Since we're dealing with []byte, we need to respect slice bounds to avoid triggering a panic() and crashing our service.

Let's look at the two ways we can decode data into Go structs and compare how one way will be safer than the other while yielding the same result. As an added bonus, we'll end up with easier to understand code.

item.title: Founding Limeleaf: Part 3, Finding Support in the Cooperative Community
item.author: John Luther
item.description: When we started Limeleaf, we wanted to do things differently. We wanted to create a democratically managed business where every worker had a voice and a stake in the company's success. In short, we wanted to start a worker cooperative (even though we don’t call ourselves that, for reasons we covered in Part 1).

item.title: Founding Limeleaf: Part 2, Writing Our Operating Agreement
item.author: John Luther
item.description: In this second installment of our series on starting a tech company as a cooperative business, we’ll discuss how we wrote our Operating Agreement (OA).

item.title: Foundling Limeleaf: Our Journey to Establishing a Cooperative Company
item.author: John Luther
item.description: At Limeleaf, how we do our work is equally important as the work itself. As we explained in a previous post, Limeleaf operates as a worker cooperative, and we are dedicated to embodying the Seven Cooperative Principles.

item.author: John Luther
